I enjoy spice, but was a little tentative since all Thai restaurants are a little different. The spice scale here is on a scale of 1 to 10 (I'm used to mild, medium, hot, and Thai hot). I went with a 5 thinking it would be comparable to hot, however should have ordered a 7 or 8. The server nicely brought out extra spice in case I needed to make it hotter.

We had a great meal and will definitely return.

I have tried this restaurant twice. The first experience I had red curry, it was good, but not the best red curry I have had. The sauce is a bit pale red and not the traditional red curry that I am used to, but still good. My friend had the Pad Thai and it was one of the best I have had. Service and experience in this visit was good. 

Second visit was with multiple friends and I had the Vietnamese Pho. I love Pho and I was disappointed. The noodles were not what I'm used to eating and the flavors weren't developed fully. All of my friends liked their dishes and I tried some of their fried rice and it had a great flavor. My friend got the Thai chicken and it was good, but filled with little bones that made it annoying to pick through. Service was slow, but acceptable. 

I would go back, but I want to try the numerous other Asian places first.

In town on business and felt like Thai  
I have an all time favorite out near Robinson but wanted to try something new. 
Had the spicy basil noodle. It is basically large noodles, meat and spice with some fried egg. 
It is decent but still doesn't beat my regular joint. 
If you are in the area and want Thai it is ok but I would probably try other places before coming back.

This place is on my top five favorite Thai spots in Pittsburgh. I work nearby, so I frequent here at least twice a week. Flavorful, fresh and simple thai food that doesn't try to reinvent the wheel. Some of my (vegetarian/vegan) favorites include the Spicy Basil Noodles with tofu- minus the egg, Fried Tofu, Coconut Galangal Soup, and fresh spring rolls. Their lemongrass mushroom soup that accompanies lunch specials is nice as well. I've gotten a lot of consistently good meals here.

The atmosphere is a few notches up from other local thai spots, with lots of aged wood, plants, and local art in every corner. The staff is always lovely and welcoming, and the asian market next door (Sweet Panda) that shares the same owners is great as well. Definitely check this place out next time you're looking to grab a bite in the South Side!

I ordered spicy basil noodles last night and was a little sad at how none spicy it was. I know everyone has a different level of what they consider to be spicy vs. mild but given the fact that a dish is called "spicy" they should ask how hot you want it.

That being said she my dish arrived it wasn't as hot a my sisters and by hot to mean temperature. My noodles were closer to warm than fresh out the pan hot but I wasn't too upset. What shocked me more was that I had to ask for extra spice. Like I said there should be a spicy rating for foods that are labeled as such. 

My sisters pho dish was spicier than mine which left me very disappointed. The best spicy basil I've had was at the green mango. They were definitely spicy and had a lot more flavor. I think I'll only come here for the pad Thai noodles. It's better here for lunch.

As one of the south sides longtime residents this place is a no brainer visit for those that want to try something new or are regular Thai-food enthusiasts. The space is quaint with authentic, but charming to decor that's not too over-the-top. The menu is huge with lots to choose from. The servers are friendly so  don't be afraid to ask questions or to ask for certain spice level. I think they are most known for their pineapple fried rice.  It's also BYOB! I nice spot, but to me, not the best Thai in Pittsburgh.

Went here again, and I guess I'm not as in love anymore. This is still a solid place to get nice portions of Thai for fair prices, but it's definitely not the healthiest option, I guess? Well, that's probably my fault for ordering a not-so-healthy noodle dish, but boy this one was swimming in its gravy.. and it was a little too salty. Hmm. 

I know I'm going to come back here... but I'll have to try something lighter next time.
The food here at Thai Me Up is amazing. The atmosphere is relaxed and the service was great! Recommend anyone in the Southside area to make it a point to eat here.

Although normally I would not have thought to try this place since I live much closer to a plethora of decent Thai places (e.g. Thai Gourmet, Pusadee's, Thai Cuisine), I stopped in to get take-out while waiting for my boyfriend to rescue me from having locked myself out of my car, which happened to be parked right in front of here.

I ordered the spicy Thai fried rice but with Thai basil added (kind of like a cross between the spicy basil noodles and the spicy fried rice) and they happily catered to my off-menu request.  Also ordered a massaman curry with chicken.  The service was very friendly, and the takeout came out in 10 minutes, which is on the fast end of my takeout experiences.  The guy behind the counter was also very kind to let me hang out inside the restaurant, at a corner table, even after I received my takeout, so that I wouldn't have to wait for my boyfriend outside in the cold!

The food itself, though, turned out to be pretty mediocre.  The basil fried rice was fine, but it didn't hold a candle to Thai Cuisine's spicy basil rice (my favorite in the city).  The flavors were not very complex and it was a tad on the salty side.  The massaman curry was better, probably better than Thai Cuisine's, and it was a good spice level.  But nothing to write home about -- Pusadee's is much better, and since we live so much closer, I doubt I'll ever trek out to the south side just to seek out the food here.

I do admit that I like the punniness of the restaurant's name, though!

I love Thai Me Up and am lucky enough to live in walking distance of it. Portions are large, prices are fair, soups and sauces are not overly salted or sugary and meat seems to be high quality (you get regular shrimp and not those dinky ones and chicken breast instead of chicken parts). They are very quick and offer great seasonal items, like the delicious pumpkin curry and mango coconut sticky rice. They are willing to accommodate special requests and don't put up a fuss about it (steamed veggies and meat), sub broccoli for bean sprouts...that sort of thing. I usually get takeout, but I know it's BYOB for dine-in. All in all, my favorite Thai place in town. My personal favorites are the Thai chicken noodle soup, pumpkin curry, pineapple curry and cashew chicken with extra chicken.

I've been here twice and the food & service were good.  I plan to visit again soon.

Joe 
Pittsburgh, Pa

I don't like to rate a restaurant based only on carry out, but my carry out pad Thai was so poor it reflects on the restaurant as a whole. I read all the reviews and was somewhat cautious, but figured : How bad could pad Thai be? Well just imagine plain sliced up chicken in spaghetti and covered in salt water. No egg, no peanuts, no lime, and certainly no flavor.  In addition, it was served in a doggy bag type plate with no utensils or soy sauce,   I'll avoid the one star rating because the ambience and decoration looked pretty good.

Was a Thai virgin now a Thai lover.  AWESOME!!!
Tried a bunch of items from the menu and the favorites are the crunchy enoki mushrooms, steamed dumplings and the Thai green curry, delicious

These folks close before the stated time.  Went in at 840 on a Saturday and were rudely turned away by the host.  I will from now on stay away and recommend everyone does as well...they clearly don't care about the customers business

Got the pho to try it. Wonton broth with some over cooked meat and none of the traditional toppings. Made me vomit at 5am like I was getting paid by the ounce. The decor is great though. But not worth the vomit.

One of the only places worth eating in the South Side. The Pad Thai is amazing, very fresh, the noodles aren't that fake orange color. I don't normally like crab Rangoon, since it's super unhealthy but it is absolutely amazing here! The flavors are to die for.
 
The service is friendly and fast, my boyfriend and I were seated right away, and our orders were taken in a timely manner. It's a small place towards the end of Carson street, a little bit away from the bar hustle. The inside is on the smaller side, it reminded me of the restaurants in NYC I used to go too. It's quaint but because of this I wouldn't recommend if you had more than four people. 

It's great food, cheap prices, and fast service.

We had been there twice. The lunch price is very good. The green curry is great. 
Tofu salad is also very good. We like the place. The only thing is it is a little far from us.

i've had really good and really bad experiences here.
the first time i went, i had some sort of curry bowl dish and it was very good. i also tried the thai tea which i really like.
the second time, they were out of both ice and tofu. it was hot outside and thank god i wasn't a vegetarian.
the third time, i got a vegetable dish. the food in general is pretty good, some more than others. the service isn't bad. and neither are the prices. the atmosphere is ok.. pretty small place though. they can be pretty slow too. seems like a better place for take out than an actual sit down dinner, but i'd still recommend trying it!
It is a really cute place with good music and great food. The service was awesome and I will definitely be coming back!

I have been to thai me up at least a dozen times now and it only gets better and better. I always get the pad thai which is my favorite I have ever had. I have also had the steamed dumplings which are great. 

Don't forget to BYOB. You can bring your own wine with just a small corkage fee. All of the meals are under 12 dollars and delicious. My buddies also really like their pineapple fried rice.

The best Thai food in Pittsburgh.  No one can step to it.  Spring rolls are delicious, curry is delicious and their pad Thai is fantastic.   Everyone on staff is really nice, it's a really cozy atmosphere and worth dealing with all ridiculous of spending time on the south side.

I discovered Thai me Up a few years ago when I was frequenting and eventually living in the Southside of Pittsburgh.  This became the place my girls and I would meet up before a night out.  As college students and young professionals, the BYOB feature is ideal for us to save a few bucks and still enjoy a great spirit with our food.  The food is great for the price and offers a variety that doesn't make you feel like you are just eating first class Chinese.  I highly recommend any of their curry dishes- try a 10 if you are into breaking a sweat over your dinner!  The only draw back of this place, and this is as of late, is that it is small.  You have to wait for a table and they tend to shuffle through customers on a busy friday or saturday night.  Weekdays go anytime, Weekends go early (before 6) or late (after 830)- either way - just go!

A sad excuse for Thai food. If you enjoy real Thai food with beautiful flavor, do not, I repeat do not come here. Unbelievably disappointed. My girlfriend and I love Thai food. We frequent Nicky's, Noodlehead, and various others in our neighborhood. Thinking this place would be pretty cool we headed over. They greeted us, sat us. Waited about 15 minutes for anyone to come to us to take any type of order. Let me mention, there were only 2 people, but we were first sat before the 3 other tables that came in. Finally someone came over, we ordered vegan Thai iced tea, cup was filled with ice, maybe 3/4 of cup of actual tea for 3.50. Waited another 15, trying to get the attention of one of the servers. We ordered the fried mushrooms, Thai me up rolls and a red curry. Before we could tell them a spice level he went away. 
The mushrooms were literally drizzlings of tempura batter. The mushrooms has disintegrated from the hot oil I imagine. No flavor or taste besides fried batter. 
Their signature Thai me up rolls which were noted to be with mint and basil-ended up being completely soggy, not a tight nor fresh spring roll. Stuffed with vermicelli and iceberg lettuce and a tiny piece of basil. 30 minutes iN, still no curry or someone to refill waters or clear plates. 
They brought out the red curry took the plates and we didn't talk to them again until the check. It was an extremely light pink color, almost white with almost no broth. We just asked for veggies-definitely frozen carrots, bamboo shoots  and broccoli. Zero spice, zero flavor. Absolutely not Thai food. Tasted like straight up coconut milk. Of course, both servers were able to straight up ignore us but not come over to see how the meal was. It was taking so long, so I tried to eat it and had another bite. They kept looking at us, ignoring us, refilling every other table with waters etc. (were both servers, so we understand how service should be given) Finally, after 25 minutes of waiting, we asked kindly if maybe we didn't get the right dish, or it was seasoned properly/unfinished, asked if we could maybe exchange for something else, she took it away, they brought the check. We took it up to the counter, proceeded to explain our disappointment, that we still offered to try something else. He was exceptionally rude and stated, 'The vegetables dilute flavor, it's why it's watery'. Thanks for admitting your curry is watery. And that logic also makes no sense. He finally said he'll take off the curry to that which we never come back. Absolutely unprofessional, kind and NOT Thai food. We tried to be kind and gentle because we get how working in a restaurant can be, and we're treated horribly. After we walked out, he literally came out the door and said 'Never come back, K, thanks bye'. Worst 'thai' restaurant in Pittsburgh.

Food was just OK. Pad Thai was very bland/dry and didn't even come with a lime- or any flavor for that matter. Pineapple fried rice had barely any pineapple in it and both portions were small for the price of the dish. Mad Noodles on East Carson wins by a long-run.

Thai Me Up is a nice little spot tucked away from the main drag in the South Side. My coworker and I wanted to check it out and so we stopped in last Monday afternoon. The space is essentially a garage with cool rustic finishes. It's a bright, pleasant little place.

They do a lunch menu with smaller portions but still plenty of options. Each entree comes with either lemongrass mushroom soup or a spring roll (or both for an extra dollar). My friend and I couldn't choose, so we opted for both. The soup was served very hot and was a nice starter. The little spring roll was also good, but it didn't really stand out from other spring rolls I've had in the past.

I ordered chicken in garlic sauce (which also had broccoli, carrots, and greens) served with white rice. I have ordered this dish from other places in the past, and have found that it is usually packed with flavor--unfortunately this time I found it to be pretty bland. The portion was generous (despite being the smaller lunch size), but I just felt like it was missing something.  

We're lucky to have a bunch of Thai options in the city, but I'm not convinced about this place yet. A lot of people seem to love it, so I might need to try again and choose something with a little more spice.

When ordering from the vegetarian portion of the menu I asked about any dairy or egg in the basil tofu and told the waiter that I was vegan.  He said that while a few of their dishes are egg and dairy free, they use fish sauce in everything on the menu - and they do not make dishes without it because it isn't authentic.  I asked if there was anything on the menu that didn't have fish sauce in it and he said that they could probably make the fried rice without fish sauce, but they definitely put oyster sauce in it.  He then told me that oyster sauce doesn't have any actual oyster extract in it so I can eat it.  Oyster sauce does have oyster extract, among other things that make up the sauce.  

Very disappointed that the waiter was so unaware and unwilling to accommodate.  Menu should be clear that Thai Me Up's version of vegetarian actually includes fish or other seafood.

Before I left for a year stint in Seattle, Thai Me Up was my *favorite* thai restaurant, well, maybe tied with Thai Place but for different things.  Thank god one of my friends ordered this dish and I found my latest obsession:  Spice Basil Noodles which I spent almost 6 months in Seattle trying all of their thai food to find out it is also called Pad Kee Mao.  It still makes my knees weak.

It's been a really really long time since I've been here. I almost forgot about the place. It may have actually been one of my first (or second) Thai places I tried. Although I believe first time may be Spice Island. Irregardless...

I was uneasy considering a lot of my friends had only rated it three stars. But the thing is, I was pleasantly surprised! Their lunch menu is super simple. One sheet with about 15ish dishes all for $6.95 AND you get soup or an egg roll (they call it spring roll, but I always consider spring rolls not fried, and this definitely hit the fryer). 

I've been branching out more in my Thai adventures, so I went with the Green Curry. All along I was thinking I'm not a fan of curry when, turns out, I'm a BIG fan of curry! I'd go so bold as to say I love it now! You know why, because it was delicious here and I love coconut anything. 

You may not get a lot in that small pot, but at the end, you're satisfied. I had large veggies like broccoli and beans with shrimp I added in. Around 4 or 5 shrimp did the job, as well as a bowl of rice on the side. I loved everything about it. The sauce was creamy and coconut-ty, with just the right spice (around a 4, I'd say. I'm a lightweight). 

What a deal, right? I'm so excited to go back. Especially considering my friends meal, the spicy noodles with tofu, was also incredibly flavorful and delicious. You've definitely won me over Thai Me Up... I'm just sad it took me so long to come back!

My favorite Thai restaurant!!  I've enjoyed the food since there open on Carson.  The new location is cool!  Excellent quality food, and great prices!!  Will recommend to any Thai food lover!  
My last visit, the food continued to exceed my expectation, and the price was great!!  I'd pay more because of the quality!!!!!!!!  

Love this place!

I was super excited when Thai Me Up moved down the street from my apartment a few weeks back and have been meaning to try it ever since - last night I finally got my chance. First I'd like to mention how much I love the venue. The "garage-door" style windows make you feel like you are sitting outside when they are open, which is great. The décor is also very nice. This is a very Americanized Thai restaurant in that the menu caters to people who are not super adventurous or are new to eating Thai food, but there are still plenty of options and it is relatively inexpensive (and BYOB!). The food was pretty good and while it is not my favorite Thai restaurant in town, I'm sure the convenience of the location will keep me coming back pretty regularly.

My husband and I ended up here after a not-so-great experience at a different restaurant down the street. We went out for Thai food and, I'm not sure why, this wasn't even on our radar initially. We walked in and were immediately greeted, handed menus, and told to sit wherever. Water was brought over immediately and drink orders were taken. The waitress/hostess/Jill of all trades that was working was so friendly and bubbly, she seemed genuinely glad there were customers, rather than other places where the staff can be kind of...blah. We ordered crab rangoon, chicken gyoza(the special of the week,) pad thai, and spicy basil noodles (which I found out is what is usually called drunken noodles elsewhere.) Everything was cooked perfectly and amazing. The spice level could have been a little more, but that is on us, because we didn't know what to expect so we didn't get it overly so the first visit. (When we reheated it, though, it was a lot spicier and still delicious!) Give this place a try, it was great and we will definitely be back.
Best Thai food in Pittsburgh. Great for take out or dine in. If you dine in, the service is great. Highly recommend the chicken pad Thai
Went again only because of a group of friends had decided. It's alright second go to.

I went to their newish home off Carson treat and was thoroughly impressed with the food. I'm not sure if they got a new cook or what happened, but the food was much better the last time I went there (when It was on carson st.)

Kudos to the chef.
Two words: Pineapple fried rice. Best thai food in Pittsburgh, and I've had it all.

I like the location of this place because it is located on a side street in a neighborhood setting. I also liked how the owners re-purposed a car glass shop for the restaurant. As far as the food, I think it is just average. The prices are reasonable and they have a rather large menu to choose from, but it's not a place that I would really have a strong desire to return to. However, it is a place I would go to and hangout with friends if we were grabbing a casual lunch in the neighborhood.
It's a nice change of pace for those who want a different flavor of Asian than just Chinese or Japanese. The restaurant itself has a nice sense of ambiance about it as well.

Given that this is the closest Thai place to me, I have reluctantly gone a few times. Always felt like I was getting hardly anything for my money, but today was definitely the last time I will ever order food from here. I ordered the red curry that I have gotten three other times for takeout. For some reason this time I received what can only be called the "snack portion" of rice and a container half the size I usually get for the curry itself. I understand raising prices, I don't, however, think you should raise prices while you simultaneously  cut the portions in half.

In terms of taste/quality of the food, the place is decent, at best. Nothing special. Try somewhere else with better food and more reasonable prices if you're looking for Thai.
